Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Physical Understanding of Matrix-stabilized Combustion in Porous Media

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of the proposed research is to develop computational and experimental methods to improve the fundamental understanding of matrix-stabilized combustion in porous media. Matrix-stabilized combustion is an advanced combustion concept in which combustion is sustained within a porous heat-conducting matrix. The internal heat recirculation within the porous matrix facilitates preheating of the unburned gas mixture, thereby enabling high-efficiency and low-pollution operations. However, the limited understanding about the combustion and heat transfer processes represents a major challenge toward the successful implementation as low-emission combustion technology for transportation and power generation.

By combining computational modeling with experimental investigations, this research seeks to enable the quantitative prediction and detailed analysis of matrix-stabilized combustion in porous media. Specifically, the goal of the computational research is to develop a high-fidelity simulation capability to enable detailed pore-resolved simulations of heterogeneous combustion processes and gas-solid interaction inside the porous structure. The experimental effort will focus on the development of advanced non-intrusive X-ray diagnostics to obtain quantitative measurements of the temperature field and combustion processes inside the porous matrix. By combining detailed simulations and experimental diagnostics, systematic investigations will be performed to obtain fundamental understanding of heterogeneous combustion processes, identify flame structure, and assess effects of operating conditions, material properties and pore topology on the flame stabilization, emissions, and combustion performance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of the proposed research program is to improve our current understanding of matrix-stabilized combustion in porous media by combining fundamental analyses, predictive modeling capabilities, and experimental investigations. Matrix-stabilized combustion in porous media is an advanced combustion concept in which combustion is sustained within a porous heat-conducting matrix. The internal heat recirculation within this matrix facilitates preheating of the unburned gas mixture, thereby enabling the extension of the lean flammability limit, increased volumetric heat-release, and significant reductions in emissions of CO and NOx. More broadly, combustion in porous media is also encountered in heterogeneous combustion processes involving bio-mass combustion, in-situ combustion, pyrolysis, and smoldering processes. The limited understanding about thermo-physico-chemical processes, involving interstitial combustion, heat-release, dispersion, conjugate heat-exchange, and effects of pore topology and material properties of the porous matrix on the internal heat-transfer are major challenges towards the successful implementation as low-emission combustion technology for transportation, power generation, and heating.

The major outcomes of this research are as follows:

1) To examine the heterogeneous combustion process in porous matrix structures and, more generally, optically inaccessible media, an in-situ simultaneous X-ray computed tomography diagnostics was developed with spatial resolution better than 20um (using X-ray synchrotron sources). This technique enables measuring the gas-phase temperature variations by combustion and density variations associated with pyrolysis and smoldering in biomass combustion. This technique was employed to examine smoldering and pyrolysis of biomass materials and for examining interstitial flame structure in porous ceramic media.

 

2) To optimize the combustion performance of porous-media burners, a computational optimization method was developed that enables the design of tailored porous-ceramic media with optimized pore topology and material properties. Direct comparisons with state-of-the-art porous-media burners demonstrated significant performance gains, both in terms of flame-stabilization and emissions.

 

3) Motivated by the computational optimization of the tailored porous media topologies, an additive manufacturing approach was devised and employed to manufacture these optimized tailored porous ceramic matrix structures. Experimental tests demonstrated the feasibility of this manufacturing approach, confirming computationally predicted performance gains.

 

4) To assess the system-level benefit of integrating porous-media burners in gas-turbines (for aviation and power-generation), a thermodynamic analysis of a Brayton cycle was performed. An extensive parametric analysis showed that the utilization of porous media burners can significantly improve emissions and thermodynamic efficiencies, which is mainly attributed to the extension of the lean flammability limited and an associated reduction in emissions and an increase in pressure ratio.

 

5) To examine to interstitial flame structure and effects of gas-phase temperature, heat-transfer, and heat conduction in the solid matrix, detailed pore-resolved simulations were performed, demonstrating the importance of fluid-structure interaction on flame stabilization and heat recirculation.
